newsitem.title: INDIA: India's Naga leaders welcome peace talks offer.
newsitem.headline: India's Naga leaders welcome peace talks offer.

text.p: Leaders of tribal Nagas in northeastern India on Wednesday welcomed initiatives by Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowda to hold peace talks with underground guerrillas to end a decades-old insurgency movement.

"We hope for a workable and acceptable solution to the burning political problem of the Nagas," A. Makan, a leader of the Naga Tribal Council (NTC), told Reuters by telephone from Kohima, capital of the mountainous state of Nagaland.

The council is said to have links with three outlawed Naga guerrilla groups fighting for a homeland for some 1.5 million ethnic Nagas who live in Nagaland and the neighbouring state of Manipur near the Burmese border.
Deve Gowda told parliament on Tuesday that he had initiated talks with an outlawed Naga insurgent group to restore peace in the region.
He did not give details on his efforts, which he mentioned in the course of a long reply to a debate on national affairs, but appealed to insurgent leaders to hold unconditional talks.
More than 1,000 people have been killed in a five-year-old feud between Nagas and their rival Kukis, who represent tribes that have a history of head-hunting.

Many of the Naga rebel leaders live in self-imposed exile outside India. Naga tribal leaders said Deve Gowda is believed to have met some leaders of the Maoist National Socialist Council of Nagaland (NSCN) during a visit to Switzerland last month.
The NSCN has two factions, while a third group, the Federal Government of Nagaland, is also part of the guerrilla movement.
Yesiuone Yevei, chairman of the Naga Tribal Council, said all three insurgent groups were willing to meet for talks with New Delhi's leaders.
"All the three groups want to share a common platform to pave the way for talks with the Centre (federal government)," he said.
NTC leader Kenito Sema told Reuters: "A message received from the NSCN leaders abroad said there will be political talks and authorised the tribal council to participate in it."
An Indian intelligence officer in Guwahati said the rebels were forced to accept peace talks after 11 of their top guerrillas were arrested last year by security forces.
